SENT.plain: Antiphospholipid antibodies (APA) have thought to be implicated in the pathogenesis of both arterial and venous thrombosis
Because of heterogeneity of APA, direct evidence of their involvement in a thrombotic event is not yet available
Development of thrombosis in the antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) may occur because of the presence of additional risk factors
Here we have analysed 60 patients with APA for the presence of the Arg506-->Gln mutation in factor V
Among them 26 suffered from deep venous thrombosis, 13 from arterial thrombosis and 21 had no history of arterial or venous thrombosis
In the first group four patients were found to be heterozygous and one homozygous for the factor V Arg506-->Gln mutation
None of the patients with the factor V mutation was found in the second and third group
The incidence of factor V mutation was significantly elevated in the group of patients with venous thrombosis
These data suggest that in patients with antiphospholipid antibodies the factor V Arg506-->Gln mutation may play a major role in the occurrence of venous thrombosis
